hints.label: def-riemann-classical
hints.title: Riemann Curvature Tensor (Classical)
hints.content:
272: :label: def-riemann-classical
273: 
274: The **Riemann curvature tensor** $R^a_{bcd}$ is defined by the commutator of covariant derivatives acting on a vector field $V^a$:
275: 
276: $$
277: [\nabla_c, \nabla_d] V^a = R^a_{bcd} V^b
278: $$
279: 
280: where $\nabla_c$ denotes covariant derivative with respect to coordinate $x^c$. In terms of Christoffel symbols:
281: 
282: $$
283: R^a_{bcd} = \frac{\partial \Gamma^a_{bd}}{\partial x^c} - \frac{\partial \Gamma^a_{bc}}{\partial x^d} + \Gamma^a_{ec} \Gamma^e_{bd} - \Gamma^a_{ed} \Gamma^e_{bc}
hints.raw_directive:
269: We now construct the **Riemann curvature tensor** from the affine connection defined in Section 1. The Riemann tensor measures the **failure of parallel transport** around closed loops—a fundamental signature of curved space.
270:

278: $$

hints.label: def-scutoid-plaquette
hints.title: Scutoid Plaquette
hints.content:
304: :label: def-scutoid-plaquette
305: 
306: Let $\mathcal{C}_i$ be a scutoid cell with parent $j$ at time $t$ and child $i$ at time $t + \Delta t$. For a shared neighbor $k \in \mathcal{N}_{\text{shared}}$, the **scutoid plaquette** $\Pi_{i,k}$ is the closed quadrilateral in spacetime with vertices:
307: 
308: $$
309: \begin{aligned}
310: p_1 &= (x_j(t), t) && \text{(parent position)} \\
311: p_2 &= (x_j(t) + \delta x_{\text{edge}}(t), t) && \text{(point on } \Gamma_{j,k}(t)) \\
312: p_3 &= (\phi_k(p_2), t + \Delta t) && \text{(corresponding point on } \Gamma_{i,k}(t + \Delta t)) \\
313: p_4 &= (x_i(t + \Delta t), t + \Delta t) && \text{(child position)}
314: \end{aligned}
315: $$
316: 
317: and edges:
318: 1. $p_1 \to p_2$: Boundary segment in $\Gamma_{j,k}(t)$
319: 2. $p_2 \to p_3$: Geodesic ruling (time evolution)
320: 3. $p_3 \to p_4$: Boundary segment in $\Gamma_{i,k}(t + \Delta t)$
321: 4. $p_4 \to p_1$: Walker trajectory (parent to child via cloning)
322: 
323: The **area** of the plaquette is:
324: 
325: $$
326: A_{\Pi_{i,k}} = \|\delta x_{\text{edge}}(t)\| \cdot \|x_i(t + \Delta t) - x_j(t)\|
327: $$
hints.raw_directive:
301: 4. A boundary segment $\Gamma_{j,k}(t)$ at time $t$ (closing the loop)

hints.label: lem-discrete-stokes-plaquette
hints.title: Discrete Stokes' Theorem for Plaquette Holonomy
hints.content:
335: :label: lem-discrete-stokes-plaquette
336: 
337: For a scutoid plaquette with four vertices $p_1, p_2, p_3, p_4$ and edge displacement vectors $\delta x_1, \delta x_2, \delta x_3, \delta x_4$, the sum of position-displacement cross-products is:
338: 
339: $$
340: \sum_{i=1}^4 \Delta x_i^d \delta x_i^b = \epsilon^{db} T^d T^b A_{\Pi} + O(A_{\Pi}^{3/2})
341: $$
342: 
343: where:
344: - $\Delta x_i^d = x_i^d - x_0^d$ is the displacement of vertex $i$ from the plaquette center $x_0$
345: - $T^d$ and $T^b$ are the tangent vectors spanning the plaquette (one spatial, one temporal)
346: - $\epsilon^{db}$ is the antisymmetric tensor (Levi-Civita symbol)
347: - $A_{\Pi}$ is the plaquette area
hints.raw_directive:
332: **Geometric Picture**: A plaquette is a "tile" on the surface of a scutoid face. If space were flat, the four edges would form a perfect parallelogram. In curved space, the quadrilateral has **excess angle** (the sum of interior angles differs from $2\pi$), and this excess is proportional to the Riemann tensor.
333: 
334: :::{prf:lemma} Discrete Stokes' Theorem for Plaquette Holonomy
335: :label: lem-discrete-stokes-plaquette
336: 
337: For a scutoid plaquette with four vertices $p_1, p_2, p_3, p_4$ and edge displacement vectors $\delta x_1, \delta x_2, \delta x_3, \delta x_4$, the sum of position-displacement cross-products is:
338: 
339: $$
340: \sum_{i=1}^4 \Delta x_i^d \delta x_i^b = \epsilon^{db} T^d T^b A_{\Pi} + O(A_{\Pi}^{3/2})
341: $$
342: 
343: where:
344: - $\Delta x_i^d = x_i^d - x_0^d$ is the displacement of vertex $i$ from the plaquette center $x_0$
345: - $T^d$ and $T^b$ are the tangent vectors spanning the plaquette (one spatial, one temporal)
346: - $\epsilon^{db}$ is the antisymmetric tensor (Levi-Civita symbol)
347: - $A_{\Pi}$ is the plaquette area

hints.label: thm-riemann-scutoid-dictionary
hints.title: Riemann-Scutoid Dictionary (Crown Jewel 1)
hints.content:
439: :label: thm-riemann-scutoid-dictionary
440: 
441: The Riemann curvature tensor can be computed from the holonomy around scutoid plaquettes. Specifically, let $V^a$ be a vector parallel-transported around the plaquette $\Pi_{i,k}$ with tangent directions $T^c$ and $T^d$ (the two independent edge directions). The vector returns to its starting point rotated by:
442: 
443: $$
444: \Delta V^a = R^a_{bcd}(x_j(t)) V^b T^c T^d A_{\Pi_{i,k}} + O(\Delta t^2, \|\delta x_{\text{edge}}\|^2)
445: $$
446: 
447: where $R^a_{bcd}(x_j(t))$ is the Riemann tensor evaluated at the parent position $x_j(t)$, and $A_{\Pi_{i,k}}$ is the area of the plaquette.
448: 
449: Equivalently, the Riemann tensor is:
450: 
451: $$
452: R^a_{bcd}(x) = \lim_{\substack{A_{\Pi} \to 0 \\ \Pi \ni x}} \frac{\Delta V^a}{V^b T^c T^d A_{\Pi}}
453: $$
hints.raw_directive:
436: **Remark (Connection to Continuous Stokes)**: In the continuous limit, the discrete sum $\sum_i$ becomes a line integral $\oint_{\partial \Pi}$, and the cross-product $\Delta x \delta x$ becomes the differential form $dx^d \wedge dx^b$. The factor $\epsilon^{db}$ ensures the correct orientation.
437:

Specifically, let $V^a$ be a vector parallel-transported around the plaquette $\Pi_{i,k}$ with tangent directions $T^c$ and $T^d$ (the two independent edge directions). The vector returns to its starting point rotated by:

hints.label: def-ricci-scalar
hints.title: Ricci Tensor and Scalar Curvature
hints.content:
560: :label: def-ricci-scalar
561: 
562: The **Ricci curvature tensor** is the trace of the Riemann tensor over the first and third indices:
563: 
564: $$
565: R_{ac} = R^b_{abc} = g^{bd} R_{dbac}
566: $$
567: 
568: The **Ricci scalar** (scalar curvature) is the trace of the Ricci tensor:
569: 
570: $$
571: R = g^{ac} R_{ac}
hints.raw_directive:
557: The Riemann tensor has $d^4$ components (in $d$ spatial dimensions), which is too many to interpret directly. We extract physically meaningful information by taking **traces**.
558: 
559: :::{prf:definition} Ricci Tensor and Scalar Curvature
560: :label: def-ricci-scalar
561: 
562: The **Ricci curvature tensor** is the trace of the Riemann tensor over the first and third indices:
563: 
564: $$
565: R_{ac} = R^b_{abc} = g^{bd} R_{dbac}
566: $$
567: 
568: The **Ricci scalar** (scalar curvature) is the trace of the Ricci tensor:
569: 
570: $$
571: R = g^{ac} R_{ac}
572: $$

hints.label: prop-ricci-from-deformation
hints.title: Ricci Tensor from Edge Deformation
hints.content:
582: :label: prop-ricci-from-deformation
583: 
584: The Ricci tensor for the emergent metric can be computed from the edge deformation tensor (Definition {prf:ref}`def-edge-deformation`):
585: 
586: $$
587: R_{ac} \Delta t = \frac{1}{|\mathcal{N}_{\text{shared}}|} \sum_{k \in \mathcal{N}_{\text{shared}}} \int_{\Gamma_{j,k}(t)} \left( D_{ac}(s) - \frac{1}{d} \text{tr}(D) \, g_{ac} \right) ds
588: $$
hints.raw_directive:
579: - In general relativity: $R_{\mu\nu} - \frac{1}{2}g_{\mu\nu}R = 8\pi G T_{\mu\nu}$ (Einstein field equation)
580:

hints.label: def-sectional-curvature
hints.title: Sectional Curvature
hints.content:
679: :label: def-sectional-curvature
680: 
681: Let $\Pi$ be a 2-dimensional plane in the tangent space $T_x \mathcal{X}$ spanned by orthonormal vectors $u^a$ and $v^b$. The **sectional curvature** of $\Pi$ is:
682: 
683: $$
684: K(u, v) = R_{abcd} u^a v^b u^c v^d
685: $$
hints.raw_directive:
676: For 2D surfaces embedded in 3D space (or 2D slices of higher-dimensional manifolds), the Riemann tensor reduces to a single scalar: the **Gaussian curvature**.
677: 
678: :::{prf:definition} Sectional Curvature
679: :label: def-sectional-curvature
680: 
681: Let $\Pi$ be a 2-dimensional plane in the tangent space $T_x \mathcal{X}$ spanned by orthonormal vectors $u^a$ and $v^b$. The **sectional curvature** of $\Pi$ is:
682: 
683: $$
684: K(u, v) = R_{abcd} u^a v^b u^c v^d
685: $$

hints.label: prop-gaussian-from-scutoid
hints.title: Gaussian Curvature from Scutoid Triangulation
hints.content:
693: :label: prop-gaussian-from-scutoid
694: 
695: For a 2D slice of the scutoid tessellation, the Gaussian curvature at a vertex $x_i$ can be computed from the **angle defect**:
696: 
697: $$
698: K(x_i) = \frac{1}{A_i} \left( 2\pi - \sum_{k \in \mathcal{N}_i} \theta_k \right)
699: $$
hints.raw_directive:
690: **Geometric Meaning**: The sectional curvature measures how much geodesic triangles on the 2D plane $\Pi$ deviate from Euclidean triangles. For a sphere of radius $r$: $K = 1/r^2$ (positive). For a hyperbolic plane: $K = -1/r^2$ (negative).
691: 
692: :::{prf:proposition} Gaussian Curvature from Scutoid Triangulation
693: :label: prop-gaussian-from-scutoid
694: 
695: For a 2D slice of the scutoid tessellation, the Gaussian curvature at a vertex $x_i$ can be computed from the **angle defect**:
696: 
697: $$
698: K(x_i) = \frac{1}{A_i} \left( 2\pi - \sum_{k \in \mathcal{N}_i} \theta_k \right)
699: $$
